profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Norwich, Conn., December 14, 1794; moved to Troy, N.Y., and thence, in 1814, to Albany, where he established himself in iron manufacturing; served in the State senate 1842-1845; alderman of Albany; mayor 1834-1837; elected as a Democrat to the Thirty-fifth Congress (March 4, 1857-March 3, 1859); unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the Thirty-sixth Congress; member of the peace conference of 1861; elected to the Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Congresses and served from March 4, 1861, to October 5, 1863, when he resigned; delegate to the State constitutional convention in 1867; died in Albany, N.Y., April 9, 1872; interment in Rural Cemetery.

researchRecord.description: The papers of Erastus Corning contain correspondence and business papers relating to his dealings with several banks, as well as companies dealing in the following: insurance, coal, steam boats, plank roads, transporting immigrants, glass works, water power, expeditions to California, iron works, land speculations, and railroads. Additional personal correspondence relating to farm business. A finding aid is available in the repository.
